Award.AwardTitle: Wrestling with pathogens: host SUMOylation and bacterial interference in the plant immune system
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental "engineering" problem in signal processing consists of integrating trigger threshold and dynamic range into a beneficial balance between sensitivity and specificity. A good example is the immune system, which organisms need to carefully control so that it can be rapidly activated when faced with a threatening pathogen, but kept in check to prevent damaging side effects. In plants, one of the strongest immune responses is triggered when intracellular immune receptors detect the presence of intruding pathogen proteins deployed by the pathogen to manipulate the host cell, a process called effector-triggered immunity. This project aims to uncover principles by which living organisms calibrate the complex signaling modules that regulate the specificity and intensity of immune responses. On a practical level, detailed knowledge of the plant immune response may lead to crop plants with improved durability of innate pathogen resistance in the long term, with significant benefits to sustainable agricultural and biomass production and the environment. This project's broader impacts also include the training of undergraduate and graduate students and of a post-doctoral researcher. In addition, the project will support students in a campus-wide program called Freshman Research in Plant Sciences (FRIPS), and will further develop connections to middle and high school teachers in Sedalia, MO, through classroom visits and the organization of research modules at MU for teachers in the summer.

The focus is on an immune regulator in the plant Arabidopsis thaliana called SRFR1. Current understanding of SRFR1 protein function suggests that SRFR1 is an immune adaptor protein that temporally and spatially regulates the presence and stability of protein complexes to fine-tune immune outputs. In this project, the mechanisms that regulate SRFR1 protein-protein interactions will be investigated. Specifically, the indication that SRFR1 binds SUMO, a small protein that is attached to other proteins to regulate their location in the cell, suggests a mechanism for regulating SRFR1 interactions with other proteins by SUMOylation. This will be tested using a combination of genetics, cell biology and proteomics to establish whether and when SUMOylation of SRFR1 client proteins occurs, and whether this determines the cellular location of protein complexes. In addition, the project will investigate if pathogens interfere with this process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the plant protein SRFR1 that, based on findings from past NSF funding, functions as a so-called adaptor protein in the plant immune system. As the name implies, adaptor proteins enable other proteins to assemble into complexes by providing an interaction platform. Hence these proteins are also sometimes called scaffold proteins. Because the plant immune system is a two-edged sword, an unregulated immune system leads to stunted growth and poor seed set in plants. This is very similar to the human immune system when it leads to allergies or autoimmune diseases. We hypothesized that SRFR1 temporally and spatially regulates the presence and stability of protein complexes to fine-tune immune outputs in order to prevent overactivity. Within this framework, we investigated the mechanisms that regulate SRFR1 protein-protein interactions using example protein interactions we had identified previously. One of these is the interaction between SRFR1 and an important positive regulator of plant immunity, EDS1. Indeed, we found that the location in the cell where SRFR1 accumulates changes with the presence or absence of EDS1 in the cell (see Figure), strongly suggesting that SRFR1 and EDS1 form a protein complex. Another protein complex that we examined was one formed by SRFR1 and members of the TCP transcription factor family. Transcription factors are proteins that regulate when and where in the organism information contained in specific genes is "read" to produce a corresponding protein.

But if an organism has to respond to changing external factors like disease-causing microbes, these protein complexes cannot be unchangeable. The organism still needs to be able to assemble and disassemble them. This project examined whether protein complex formation involving SRFR1 is regulated by a process by which a small protein called SUMO is attached to a partner of SRFR1 (for example EDS1 and TCPs). SUMO would then serve like a handle by which SRFR1 could hold on to the partner protein. Results from this project support our hypothesis. As a next step, we will want to understand different protein complex compositions in living plants, and how the process of attaching SUMO to partner proteins itself is regulated.

Intellectual merit - A fundamental problem every organism has to solve consists of being responsive to environmental challenges without overreacting to the point where the response is more damaging than the original threat. In the case of the immune system, this seems to be especially important, since the response is often potent and aimed at negatively affecting living (ideally foreign) cells. Adaptor proteins are thought to play a crucial role in this decision process. The protein complexes we identified as having important regulatory roles in the plant immune system serve as an example how such complexes can be modulated by regulated protein interactions. Such basic principles have implications beyond plant biology or the immune system.

Broader impacts - This project provided training and educational activities for high school, undergraduate and graduate students, as well as post-doctoral researchers. In many cases, this training directly has led to employment for graduate students and post-doctoral researchers, and to admission to graduate programs for undergraduates. More broadly, this project led to a better understanding how the plant immune system impacts normal plant growth and how these two processes are regulated in opposite directions. Such insights will provide opportunities to adjust the plant immune system in crop plants for better protection against disease-causing agents while minimizing yield penalties.
